Facsimile Images

Sanc̣tissimae
⸢coniugi⸣ Zosime
[fi]del[i], ⸢q⸣ ⸢quae⸣ ⸢vixit⸣
ann (is) XXVI et de-
5ce[s]sit XI Kal (endas) Octobris
Amantio
et Albino cons (ulibus)

Apparatus criticus

English translation

For my most holy wife, Zosime, strong in faith, who lived for 26 years and departed 11 days before the Kalends of October, in the consulship of Amantius and Albinus (= 21 September 345 AD)

Italian translation

Per la mia santissima moglie, Zosime, forte nella fede, che ha vissuto per 26 anni e se ne andò 11 giorni prima delle calende di ottobre, sotto il consolato di Amantius e Albino (21 settembre 345 d.C.).

commentary

This is one of relatively few Christian epitaphs in Latin from Catania. The name Zosime is a common Greek one, found several times in eastern Sicily. Giving a date by referring to the consuls in office during that year reflects standard Roman dating practice, but giving the precise date of death in a funerary inscription is a distinctive feature of Christian funerary epigraphy, and this is one of the earliest Sicilian examples to use a consular date. The misspelling of vixit as bixsit reflects a common confusion of ‘B’ and ‘V’ (due to a merging of the sound represented by each letter in Latin). This is more common in southern than northern Italy, and in this case may well represent the influence of Greek (where use of β for a Latin V is commonplace; see no.24).

bibliography

    1933.0029 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001283 1932.0072 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001283 165 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000028 Agnello 1953 no.88 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002211 Libertini 1931 48 no.2 = Libertini (1981) 97 no.2 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001870 Libertini NSA 1931 370 no.1 = Libertini (1981) 112 no.1 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001392 Ferrua 1982-1983 4 no.2 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001996 Ferrua 1989 no.422 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001995
